column2: Narrative Continued by the Doctor: The Jolly-boat's Last Trip
column3: Narrative Continued by the Doctor: The Jolly boat's Last Trip

column2: THIS fifth trip was quite different from any of the others.
column3: THIS fifth trip was quite different from any of the others.

column2: In the first place, the little gallipot of a boat that we were in was gravely overloaded.
column3: In the first place, the little gallipot of a boat that we were in was gravely overloaded.

column2: Five grown men, and three of them--Trelawney, Redruth, and the captain--over six feet high, was already more than she was meant to carry.
column3: Five grown men, and three of them-Trelawney, Redruth, and the captain-over six feet high, was already more than she was meant to carry.

column2: Add to that the powder, pork, and bread-bags.
column3: Add to that the powder, pork, and bread bags.

column2: The gunwale was lipping astern.
column3: The gunwale was lipping astern.

column2: Several times we shipped a little water, and my breeches and the tails of my coat were all soaking wet before we had gone a hundred yards.
column3: Several times we shipped a little water, and my breeches and the tails of my coat were all soaking wet before we had gone a hundred yards.

column2: All the same, we were afraid to breathe.
column3: All the same, we were afraid to breathe.

column2: Even the ripples were a danger to our overloaded craft, but the worst of it was that we were swept out of our true course and away from our proper landing-place behind the point.
column3: Even the ripples were a danger to our overloaded craft, but the worst of it was that we were swept out of our true course and away from our proper landing place behind the point.

column2: I cannot keep her head for the stockade, sir, said I to the captain. I was steering, while he and Redruth, two fresh men, were at the oars. "The tide keeps washing her down.
column3: I cannot keep her head for the stockade, sir, said I to the captain. I was steering, while he and Redruth, two fresh men, were at the oars. "The tide keeps washing her down.

column2: Could you pull a little stronger?"
column3: Could you pull a little stronger?"

column2: You must bear up, sir, if you please--bear up until you see you're gaining.
column3: You must bear up, sir, if you please-bear up until you see you're gaining.

column2: I tried and found by experiment that the tide kept sweeping us westward until I had laid her head due east, or just about right angles to the way we ought to go.
column3: I tried and found by experiment that the tide kept sweeping us westward until I had laid her head due east, or just about right angles to the way we ought to go.

column2: We'll never get ashore at this rate, said I.
column3: We'll never get ashore at this rate, said i

column2: If it's the only course that we can lie, sir, we must even lie it, returned the captain.
column3: If it's the only course that we can lie, sir, we must even lie it, returned the captain.

column2: We must keep upstream.	We must keep upstream.
Thank you, my man, said I, quite as if nothing had happened, for we had all quietly made up our minds to treat him like one of ourselves.
column3: Thank you, my man, said I, quite as if nothing had happened, for we had all quietly made up our minds to treat him like one of ourselves.

column2: Suddenly the captain spoke up again, and I thought his voice was a little changed.
column3: Suddenly the captain spoke up again, and I thought his voice was a little changed.

column2: The gun! said he.
column3: The gun! said he.

column2: They could never get the gun ashore, and if they did, they could never haul it through the woods.
column3: They could never get the gun ashore, and if they did, they could never haul it through the woods.

column2: Look astern, doctor, replied the captain.
column3: Look astern, doctor, replied the captain.

column2: We had entirely forgotten the long nine; and there, to our horror, were the five rogues busy about her, getting off her jacket, as they called the stout tarpaulin cover under which she sailed.
column3: We had entirely forgotten the long nine; and there, to our horror, were the five rogues busy about her, getting off her jacket, as they called the stout tarpaulin cover under which she sailed.

column2: Israel was Flint's gunner, said Gray hoarsely.
column3: Israel was Flint's gunner, said Gray hoarsely.

column2: At any risk, we put the boat's head direct for the landing-place.
column3: At any risk, we put the boat's head direct for the landing place.

column2: By this time we had got so far out of the run of the current that we kept steerage way even at our necessarily gentle rate of rowing, and I could keep her steady for the goal.
column3: By this time we had got so far out of the run of the current that we kept steerage way even at our necessarily gentle rate of rowing, and I could keep her steady for the goal.

column2: I could hear as well as see that brandy-faced rascal Israel Hands plumping down a round-shot on the deck.
column3: I could hear as well as see that brandy faced rascal Israel Hands plumping down a round shot on the deck.

column2: Who's the best shot? asked the captain.
column3: Who's the best shot? asked the captain.

column2: Mr. Trelawney, will you please pick me off one of these men, sir? Hands, if possible, said the captain.
column3: mr Trelawney, will you please pick me off one of these men, sir? Hands, if possible, said the captain.

column2: He looked to the priming of his gun.
column3: He looked to the priming of his gun.

column2: Now, cried the captain, "easy with that gun, sir, or you'll swamp the boat.
column3: Now, cried the captain, "easy with that gun, sir, or you'll swamp the boat.

column2: All hands stand by to trim her when he aims."
column3: All hands stand by to trim her when he aims."

column2: They had the gun, by this time, slewed round upon the swivel, and Hands, who was at the muzzle with the rammer, was in consequence the most exposed.
column3: They had the gun, by this time, slewed round upon the swivel, and Hands, who was at the muzzle with the rammer, was in consequence the most exposed.

column2: However, we had no luck, for just as Trelawney fired, down he stooped, the ball whistled over him, and it was one of the other four who fell.
column3: However, we had no luck, for just as Trelawney fired, down he stooped, the ball whistled over him, and it was one of the other four who fell.

column2: The cry he gave was echoed not only by his companions on board but by a great number of voices from the shore, and looking in that direction I saw the other pirates trooping out from among the trees and tumbling into their places in the boats.
column3: The cry he gave was echoed not only by his companions on board but by a great number of voices from the shore, and looking in that direction I saw the other pirates trooping out from among the trees and tumbling into their places in the boats.

column2: Give way, then, cried the captain.
column3: Give way, then, cried the captain.

column2: We mustn't mind if we swamp her now.	We mustn't mind if we swamp her now.
If we can't get ashore, all's up."
column3: If we can't get ashore, all's up."

column2: They'll have a hot run, sir, returned the captain.
column3: They'll have a hot run, sir, returned the captain.

column2: Jack ashore, you know.	Jack ashore, you know.
It's not them I mind; it's the round-shot.
column3: It's not them I mind; it's the round shot.

column2: Carpet bowls!
column3: Carpet bowls!

column2: My lady's maid couldn't miss.
column3: My lady's maid couldn't miss.

column2: Tell us, squire, when you see the match, and we'll hold water."
column3: Tell us, squire, when you see the match, and we'll hold water."

column2: In the meanwhile we had been making headway at a good pace for a boat so overloaded, and we had shipped but little water in the process.
column3: In the meanwhile we had been making headway at a good pace for a boat so overloaded, and we had shipped but little water in the process.

column2: We were now close in; thirty or forty strokes and we should beach her, for the ebb had already disclosed a narrow belt of sand below the clustering trees.
column3: We were now close in; thirty or forty strokes and we should beach her, for the ebb had already disclosed a narrow belt of sand below the clustering trees.

column2: The gig was no longer to be feared; the little point had already concealed it from our eyes.
column3: The gig was no longer to be feared; the little point had already concealed it from our eyes.

column2: The ebb-tide, which had so cruelly delayed us, was now making reparation and delaying our assailants.
column3: The ebb tide, which had so cruelly delayed us, was now making reparation and delaying our assailants.

column2: The one source of danger was the gun.
column3: The one source of danger was the gun.

column2: If I durst, said the captain, "I'd stop and pick off another man."
column3: If I durst, said the captain, "I'd stop and pick off another man."

column2: But it was plain that they meant nothing should delay their shot.
column3: But it was plain that they meant nothing should delay their shot.

column2: They had never so much as looked at their fallen comrade, though he was not dead, and I could see him trying to crawl away.
column3: They had never so much as looked at their fallen comrade, though he was not dead, and I could see him trying to crawl away.

column2: Ready! cried the squire.
column3: Ready! cried the squire.

column2: Hold! cried the captain, quick as an echo.
column3: Hold! cried the captain, quick as an echo.

column2: And he and Redruth backed with a great heave that sent her stern bodily under water.
column3: And he and Redruth backed with a great heave that sent her stern bodily under water.

column2: This was the first that Jim heard, the sound of the squire's shot not having reached him.
column3: This was the first that Jim heard, the sound of the squire's shot not having reached him.

column2: Where the ball passed, not one of us precisely knew, but I fancy it must have been over our heads and that the wind of it may have contributed to our disaster.
column3: Where the ball passed, not one of us precisely knew, but I fancy it must have been over our heads and that the wind of it may have contributed to our disaster.

column2: So far there was no great harm.
column3: So far there was no great harm.

column2: Mine I had snatched from my knees and held over my head, by a sort of instinct.
column3: Mine I had snatched from my knees and held over my head, by a sort of instinct.

column2: The other three had gone down with the boat.
column3: The other three had gone down with the boat.

column2: With all this in our minds, we waded ashore as fast as we could, leaving behind us the poor jolly-boat and a good half of all our powder and provisions.
column3: With all this in our minds, we waded ashore as fast as we could, leaving behind us the poor jolly boat and a good half of all our powder and provisions.
